messages.message: oh is the original file upside-down already?
i’ll look into this later. i have to work on something else first, but yeah curious why this is only happening with correct_orientation on
oh wait did you rotate it to be upside down @Kerry? it could be it’s just not handling upside-down files well?
btw @Balaram as a temporary solution, you can try using correct_orientation_coarse=True as well
yes it’s not handling upside down
correct_orientation_coarse will not help, i think

remember a while ago we have this google ocr bug that when scanning upside down documents, all the words are scanned correctly but the location of the words is all messed up - the location is still upside down
oh is it cuz the words are still ocr-ed correctly so everything is proper english text? just that it’s not in the right orientation?
Yes, all the words are scanned properly; it is the locations of the words are wrong
right. i think that would prevent correct_orientation_coarse from working, since it looks to see which orientation has the most correct english words
@Jonathan Shih I have copied the original file to the input folder. you can take a look on it
:+1: thanks. have to resolve some numpy stuff first, but will get to this right after
I can take look when I get in. I remember seeing this with some citi documents too
Specifically when there were a few words on the page that were upside down

I am quite certain that this is related to this old issue back in March. It’s a bug of how we turn Google OCR result into a text file.
https://instabase.slack.com/archives/CFAC0MAKT/p1552938099040400
GoogOcr would flip the entire page
Yes sound similar to what Kerry is describing

yes that is what we expect from upside down words. i wonder if the issue is actually that because i was using a vertical line to calculate the angle, something was screwing up with a divide by 0. or something related to which line i’m picking to calculate the angle
@Jonathan Shih let’s sync up when I get in office in like 15 minutes
